channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: World’s biggest set of human genome sequences opens to scientists
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03763-3

The whole genomes of 500,000 people in the UK Biobank will help researchers to probe our genetic code for links to disease.
item.dc:title: World’s biggest set of human genome sequences opens to scientists
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.title: Accelerating ‘Oumuamua with H<sub>2</sub> is challenging
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06697-y

Accelerating ‘Oumuamua with H2 is challenging
item.dc:title: Accelerating ‘Oumuamua with H<sub>2</sub> is challenging
item.dc:creator: Niels F. W. Ligterink

item.title: Reply to: Accelerating ‘Oumuamua with H<sub>2</sub> is challenging
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06698-x

Reply to: Accelerating ‘Oumuamua with H2 is challenging
item.dc:title: Reply to: Accelerating ‘Oumuamua with H<sub>2</sub> is challenging
item.dc:creator: Jennifer B. Bergner
Darryl Z. Seligman

item.title: Cellular development and evolution of the mammalian cerebellum
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06884-x

Cellular development and evolution of the mammalian cerebellum
item.dc:title: Cellular development and evolution of the mammalian cerebellum

item.title: Why COP28 probably won’t keep the 1.5 degree dream alive
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03773-1

We discuss the challenges of the upcoming climate-change conference, and a way to make stable plasma using hairy blocks.
item.dc:title: Why COP28 probably won’t keep the 1.5 degree dream alive
item.dc:creator: Nick Petrić Howe
Shamini Bundell

item.title: Super hot plasma made easy with stabilising fibres
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03776-y

Carbon fibre blocks could make it easier to create uniform high temperature plasma for manufacturing and research.
item.dc:title: Super hot plasma made easy with stabilising fibres
item.dc:creator: Shamini Bundell

item.title: Karen Kaplan (1959–2023)
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03772-2

Karen Kaplan (1959–2023)
item.dc:title: Karen Kaplan (1959–2023)

item.title: A stable atmospheric-pressure plasma for extreme-temperature synthesis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06694-1

A plasma set-up consisting of a pair of carbon-fibre-tip-enhanced electrodes enables the generation of a uniform, ultra-high temperature and stable plasma (up to 8,000  K) at atmospheric pressure using a combination of vertically oriented long and short carbon fibres.
item.dc:title: A stable atmospheric-pressure plasma for extreme-temperature synthesis

item.title: MSL2 ensures biallelic gene expression in mammals
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06781-3

After loss of MSL2, a class of dosage-sensitive genes transitions from biallelic to monoallelic expression, whereby one allele remains active, retaining active histone modifications and transcription factor binding, and the other allele is silenced, exhibiting loss of promoter–enhancer contacts and the acquisition of DNA methylation.
item.dc:title: MSL2 ensures biallelic gene expression in mammals
item.dc:creator: Yidan Sun

item.title: An autonomous laboratory for the accelerated synthesis of novel materials
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06734-w

An autonomous laboratory, the A-Lab, is presented that combines computations, literature data, machine learning and active learning, which discovered and synthesized 41 novel compounds from a set of 58 targets after 17 days of operation.
item.dc:title: An autonomous laboratory for the accelerated synthesis of novel materials
item.dc:creator: Nathan J. Szymanski

item.title: On-surface synthesis of aromatic cyclo[10]carbon and cyclo[14]carbon
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06741-x

We provide a modified strategy for the on-surface synthesis of cyclocarbons with 10 or 14 carbon atoms that provides a route for characterizing annular carbon allotropes.
item.dc:title: On-surface synthesis of aromatic cyclo[10]carbon and cyclo[14]carbon
item.dc:creator: Luye Sun
Wei Zheng
Wenze Gao
Faming Kang
Mali Zhao
Wei Xu

item.title: FOXP3 recognizes microsatellites and bridges DNA through multimerization
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06793-z

FOXP3 uses the forkhead domain to form a higher-order multimer after binding to TnG repeat microsatellites.
item.dc:title: FOXP3 recognizes microsatellites and bridges DNA through multimerization
item.dc:creator: Wenxiang Zhang
Fangwei Leng
Xi Wang
Ricardo N. Ramirez
Jinseok Park
Christophe Benoist
Sun Hur

item.title: Identification of constrained sequence elements across 239 primate genomes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06798-8

Whole-genome alignment of 239 primate species reveals noncoding regulatory elements that are under selective constraint in primates but not in other placental mammals, that are enriched for variants that affect human gene expression and complex traits in diseases.
item.dc:title: Identification of constrained sequence elements across 239 primate genomes

item.title: A resonant sextuplet of sub-Neptunes transiting the bright star HD 110067
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06692-3

Observations of six transiting planets around the bright nearby star HD 110067 show that they follow a chain of resonant orbits, with three of the planets inferring the presence of large hydrogen-dominated atmospheres.
item.dc:title: A resonant sextuplet of sub-Neptunes transiting the bright star HD 110067

item.title: Landscape dynamics and the Phanerozoic diversification of the biosphere
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06777-z

A model of sediment flux from the land to the oceans over the Phanerozoic eon explains differences in the fossil records of marine animal genera and land plant genera.
item.dc:title: Landscape dynamics and the Phanerozoic diversification of the biosphere
item.dc:creator: Tristan Salles
Laurent Husson
Manon Lorcery
Beatriz Hadler Boggiani

item.title: Exploring large-scale entanglement in quantum simulation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06768-0

On a 51-ion quantum simulator, we investigate locality of entanglement Hamiltonians for a Heisenberg chain, demonstrating Bisognano–Wichmann predictions of quantum field theory applied to lattice many-body systems, and observe the transition from area- to volume-law scaling of entanglement entropies.
item.dc:title: Exploring large-scale entanglement in quantum simulation
item.dc:creator: Manoj K. Joshi
Christian Kokail
Rick van Bijnen
Florian Kranzl
Torsten V. Zache
Rainer Blatt
Christian F. Roos
Peter Zoller

item.title: Associative pyridinium electrolytes for air-tolerant redox flow batteries
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06664-7

The redox behaviour of pyridinium electrolytes under representative flow battery conditions is investigated, offering insights into air tolerance of batteries containing these electrolytes while providing a universal physico-chemical descriptor of their reversibility.
item.dc:title: Associative pyridinium electrolytes for air-tolerant redox flow batteries
item.dc:creator: Mark E. Carrington
Kamil Sokołowski
Erlendur Jónsson
Evan Wenbo Zhao
Anton M. Graf
Israel Temprano
Jade A. McCune
Clare P. Grey
Oren A. Scherman

item.title: The genetic legacy of the expansion of Bantu-speaking peoples in Africa
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06770-6

We gathered genetic data for 1,763 individuals from 147 populations across 14 African countries, and 12 Late Iron Age individuals, to trace the expansion of Bantu-speaking peoples over the past 6,000 years.
item.dc:title: The genetic legacy of the expansion of Bantu-speaking peoples in Africa
item.dc:creator: Cesar A. Fortes-Lima

item.title: Ending extreme poverty has a negligible impact on global greenhouse gas emissions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06679-0

Global emissions associated with the economic growth needed to alleviate extreme poverty are limited.
item.dc:title: Ending extreme poverty has a negligible impact on global greenhouse gas emissions
item.dc:creator: Philip Wollburg
Stephane Hallegatte
Daniel Gerszon Mahler

item.title: Scaling deep learning for materials discovery
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06735-9

A protocol using large-scale training of graph networks enables high-throughput discovery of novel stable structures and led to the identification of 2.2 million crystal structures, of which 381,000 are newly discovered stable materials.
item.dc:title: Scaling deep learning for materials discovery
item.dc:creator: Amil Merchant
Simon Batzner
Samuel S. Schoenholz
Muratahan Aykol
Gowoon Cheon
Ekin Dogus Cubuk

item.title: Pesticide use negatively affects bumble bees across European landscapes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06773-3

Results from 316 Bombus terrestris colonies at 106 agricultural sites across eight European countries find pesticides in bumble bee pollen to be associated with reduced colony performance, especially in areas of intensive agriculture.
item.dc:title: Pesticide use negatively affects bumble bees across European landscapes
item.dc:creator: Charlie C. Nicholson
Jessica Knapp

item.title: mRNA reading frame maintenance during eukaryotic ribosome translocation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06780-4

The accuracy of eukaryotic ribosome translocation relies on eukaryote-specific elements of the 80S ribosome, elongation factor 2 and transfer RNAs, all of which contribute to the maintenance of the messenger RNA reading frame.
item.dc:title: mRNA reading frame maintenance during eukaryotic ribosome translocation
item.dc:creator: Nemanja Milicevic
Lasse Jenner
Alexander Myasnikov
Marat Yusupov
Gulnara Yusupova

item.title: Human mobility networks reveal increased segregation in large cities
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06757-3

There is extreme socioeconomic segregation in large US cities, arising from a greater choice of differentiated spaces targeted to specific socioeconomic groups, which can be countered by positioning city hubs (such as shopping centres) to bridge diverse neighbourhoods.
item.dc:title: Human mobility networks reveal increased segregation in large cities
item.dc:creator: Hamed Nilforoshan
Wenli Looi
Emma Pierson
Blanca Villanueva
Nic Fishman
Yiling Chen
John Sholar
Beth Redbird
David Grusky
Jure Leskovec

item.title: Evidence for chiral supercurrent in quantum Hall Josephson junctions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06764-4

Ultra-narrow quantum Hall Josephson junctions defined in encapsulated graphene nanoribbons exhibit a chiral supercurrent, visible up to 8  T.
item.dc:title: Evidence for chiral supercurrent in quantum Hall Josephson junctions
item.dc:creator: Hadrien Vignaud
David Perconte
Wenmin Yang
Bilal Kousar
Edouard Wagner
Frédéric Gay
Kenji Watanabe

Hermann Sellier
Benjamin Sacépé

item.title: Disease-specific tau filaments assemble via polymorphic intermediates
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06788-w

A time-resolved cryogenic electron microscopy analysis provides structural information on the processes of primary and secondary nucleation of tau amyloid formation, with implications for the development of new therapies.
item.dc:title: Disease-specific tau filaments assemble via polymorphic intermediates
item.dc:creator: Sofia Lövestam
David Li
Jane L. Wagstaff
Abhay Kotecha
Dari Kimanius
Stephen H. McLaughlin
Alexey G. Murzin
Stefan M. V. Freund
Michel Goedert
Sjors H. W. Scheres

item.title: Cascaded compression of size distribution of nanopores in monolayer graphene
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06689-y

Cascaded compression, in which nanopores are compressed by cycles of shrinkage and expansion, is described, leading tohigh-density nanopores in monolayer graphene with a narrow pore-size distribution, left skewness and ultrasmall tail deviation.
item.dc:title: Cascaded compression of size distribution of nanopores in monolayer graphene
item.dc:creator: Jiangtao Wang
Chi Cheng
Xudong Zheng
Juan Carlos Idrobo

Ji-Hoon Park

Lain-Jong Li

Jing Kong

item.title: A probable Keplerian disk feeding an optically revealed massive young star
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06790-2

The authors suggest that a probable Keplerian disk is feeding an optically revealed massive young stellar object in the Large Magellanic Cloud.
item.dc:title: A probable Keplerian disk feeding an optically revealed massive young star
item.dc:creator: Anna F. McLeod
Pamela D. Klaassen
Megan Reiter
Jonathan Henshaw
Rolf Kuiper
Adam Ginsburg

item.title: Remote collaboration fuses fewer breakthrough ideas
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06767-1

Analysis of research articles and patent applications shows that members of teams that collaborate remotely are less likely to make breakthrough discoveries than members of on-site teams.
item.dc:title: Remote collaboration fuses fewer breakthrough ideas
item.dc:creator: Yiling Lin
Carl Benedikt Frey
Lingfei Wu

item.title: The genetic diversity of Bantu-speaking populations helped to shape African history
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03379-7

Analysis of a massive genomic data set reveals the profound effects that the movement of Bantu-speaking peoples had on Africa’s biological, linguistic and cultural landscape. These findings provide valuable insights for a wide range of disciplines and serve as a comprehensive data set of ancient and modern African individuals for comparative studies.
item.dc:title: The genetic diversity of Bantu-speaking populations helped to shape African history

item.title: Global science is splintering into two — and this is becoming a problem
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03711-1

The United States and China are pursuing parallel scientific tracks. To solve crises on multiple fronts, the two roads need to become one.
item.dc:title: Global science is splintering into two — and this is becoming a problem

item.title: Carbon rings push limits of chemical theories
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03575-5

Scientists are tantalized by the many forms that carbon could adopt — some of which are predicted to have extraordinary properties. The synthesis of three new all-carbon molecules is therefore a source of excitement.
item.dc:title: Carbon rings push limits of chemical theories
item.dc:creator: Przemysław Gaweł
Cina Foroutan-Nejad

item.title: Tackling extreme poverty around the world need not impede climate action
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03627-w

A study has revealed that eliminating extreme poverty would result in a relatively small increase in global greenhouse-gas emissions, dispelling the idea that efforts to combat climate change and poverty are incompatible.
item.dc:title: Tackling extreme poverty around the world need not impede climate action
item.dc:creator: Katharine L. Ricke
Gordon C. McCord

item.title: How does it feel to have an octopus arm? This robo-tentacle lets people find out
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03759-z

Mimicking the snatch and grab of an octopus snaring its prey required a new way of thinking about robotics.
item.dc:title: How does it feel to have an octopus arm? This robo-tentacle lets people find out
item.dc:creator: Bianca Nogrady

item.title: A new kind of solar cell is coming: is it the future of green energy?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03714-y

Firms commercializing perovskite–silicon ‘tandem’ photovoltaics say that the panels will be more efficient and could lead to cheaper electricity.
item.dc:title: A new kind of solar cell is coming: is it the future of green energy?
item.dc:creator: Mark Peplow

item.title: Whole-genome alignment with primates reveals DNA elements conserved in humans
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03641-y

By comparing DNA sequences across hundreds of species of primates and other mammals, an analysis identifies non-coding regulatory elements that are conserved only in primates and that could have important roles in complex traits and diseases in humans.
item.dc:title: Whole-genome alignment with primates reveals DNA elements conserved in humans

item.title: ChatGPT for chemistry: AI and robots join forces to build new materials
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03745-5

Google DeepMind tool predicts nearly 400,000 stable substances, and an autonomous system learns to make them in the lab.
item.dc:title: ChatGPT for chemistry: AI and robots join forces to build new materials
item.dc:creator: Mark Peplow

item.title: Atomic-level structures show how accuracy is maintained in protein synthesis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03382-y

A series of structures of the eukaryotic protein-synthesis machinery are imaged at high resolution in defined states of the elongation phase of protein synthesis. Analysis suggests that there are underlying molecular mechanisms that increase the accuracy of translation of genetic information in eukaryotes.
item.dc:title: Atomic-level structures show how accuracy is maintained in protein synthesis

item.title: ‘Disruptive’ science more likely from teams who work in the same place
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03618-x

Analysis of millions of papers shows that farflung collaborators produce fewer big breakthroughs than groups working together in person.
item.dc:title: ‘Disruptive’ science more likely from teams who work in the same place
item.dc:creator: David Adam

item.title: Stuck in the middle
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03724-w

What more could you want?
item.dc:title: Stuck in the middle
item.dc:creator: David Lee Zweifler

item.title: The myth of cosmopolitan cities: why large urban areas are more segregated
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03373-z

There is a long-standing assumption that large, densely populated cities inherently foster interactions between a diverse range of people. Analysis of 1.6 billion person-to-person encounters in the United States reveals that big cities are actually pockets of extreme segregation, highlighting a need for strategic urban design that fosters more integrated environments.
item.dc:title: The myth of cosmopolitan cities: why large urban areas are more segregated

item.title: Why has swine flu emerged in a person in the UK — and what’s next?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03774-0

Scientists are closely monitoring a virus that has been detected in a person in the UK for the first time.
item.dc:title: Why has swine flu emerged in a person in the UK — and what’s next?
item.dc:creator: Katharine Sanderson

item.title: Pesticide cocktails harm bumblebees in European fields
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03644-9

Exposure to the complex mix of pesticides used in agriculture in Europe significantly reduces bumblebees’ health. This suggests that current risk-assessment processes, in which pesticides are assessed separately, are not fit for purpose. Continuous monitoring is needed to quantify the real-world effects of pesticides on pollinator health.
item.dc:title: Pesticide cocktails harm bumblebees in European fields

item.title: Why is China’s high-quality research footprint becoming more introverted?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03762-4

Data from the Nature Index suggest China-based authors are increasingly publishing without international colleagues.
item.dc:title: Why is China’s high-quality research footprint becoming more introverted?
item.dc:creator: Brian Owens

item.title: The overlooked role of landscape dynamics in steering biodiversity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03536-y

Scientists have long sought to understand what drives biodiversity changes. A study unifies ideas about marine and terrestrial biodiversity in one explanatory framework, pointing to physical geography as dictating life’s trajectory.
item.dc:title: The overlooked role of landscape dynamics in steering biodiversity
item.dc:creator: Alexandre Pohl

item.title: An immune-cell transcription factor tethers DNA together
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03628-9

A transcription factor in immune cells forms an unexpectedly ladder-like complex with two DNA molecules, allowing the expression of genes that these cells need to suppress harmful immune responses.
item.dc:title: An immune-cell transcription factor tethers DNA together
item.dc:creator: Zhi Liu
Ye Zheng

item.title: State governments could revolutionize health-care data
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03741-9

State governments could revolutionize health-care data
item.dc:title: State governments could revolutionize health-care data
item.dc:creator: Andrew Burt
Daniel Boffa

item.title: From the archive: renaming the proton, and enthusiasm for sanitary matters
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03702-2

Snippets from Nature’s past.
item.dc:title: From the archive: renaming the proton, and enthusiasm for sanitary matters

item.title: Extraterrestrial life: back story for the control experiment
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03742-8

Extraterrestrial life: back story for the control experiment
item.dc:title: Extraterrestrial life: back story for the control experiment
item.dc:creator: Manuel Lerdau

item.title: Huge survey finds US$10,000 pay gap for disabled scientists
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03738-4

Disabled people with STEM PhDs earn less than their non-disabled colleagues.
item.dc:title: Huge survey finds US$10,000 pay gap for disabled scientists
item.dc:creator: Miryam Naddaf

item.title: Submitting papers to several journals at once
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03740-w

Submitting papers to several journals at once
item.dc:title: Submitting papers to several journals at once
item.dc:creator: Josephat U. Izunobi

item.title: Adjust the format of papers to improve description by AI
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03739-3

Adjust the format of papers to improve description by AI
item.dc:title: Adjust the format of papers to improve description by AI
item.dc:creator: Terence Day

item.title: China and California are leading the way on climate cooperation. Others should follow
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03713-z

California governor Gavin Newsom’s delegation is building on existing research and policy initiatives with China, showing that effective climate action can happen below the national level.
item.dc:title: China and California are leading the way on climate cooperation. Others should follow
item.dc:creator: Fan Dai

item.title: Daily briefing: Data centres’ huge ‘water footprint’ becomes clear amid AI boom
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03768-y

‘Thirsty’ computing hubs could put pressure on already stretched water resources in sub-Saharan Africa. Plus, GPT-4 generates fake data set to support bogus science and what the OpenAI drama means for AI progress — and safety.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Data centres’ huge ‘water footprint’ becomes clear amid AI boom
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: How effective are climate protests at swaying policy — and what could make a difference?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03721-z

Why people take to the streets to march against global heating is relatively well documented. But it’s unclear why certain tactics work better than others in reaching the public and policymakers.
item.dc:title: How effective are climate protests at swaying policy — and what could make a difference?
item.dc:creator: Dana R. Fisher
Oscar Berglund
Colin J. Davis

item.title: How the ‘right to science’ can help us overcome the many crises we face today
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03712-0

The Universal Declaration of Human Rights — proclaimed 75 years ago — describes science as fundamental to humanity. Upholding this right has never been more relevant than it is now.
item.dc:title: How the ‘right to science’ can help us overcome the many crises we face today

item.title: ‘My collaborations would see me jailed’: Australian researchers fear proposed new laws
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03731-x

Under the proposal, technology with potential military use would need authorization to be shared with non-Australian colleagues.
item.dc:title: ‘My collaborations would see me jailed’: Australian researchers fear proposed new laws
item.dc:creator: Bianca Nogrady

item.title: This is how the world finally ends the HIV/AIDS pandemic
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03715-x

Putting the specific needs of individuals and communities at the heart of HIV/AIDS care, by harnessing behavioural science, is key to building on the progress already been made.
item.dc:title: This is how the world finally ends the HIV/AIDS pandemic
item.dc:creator: John Nkengasong
Mike Reid
Ingrid T. Katz

item.title: These volunteers want to be infected with disease to aid research — will their altruism help?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03583-5

An advocacy group is pushing for more ‘human challenge’ trials to spur vaccine discovery. Following COVID-19 and Zika studies, hepatitis C could be next.
item.dc:title: These volunteers want to be infected with disease to aid research — will their altruism help?
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.title: Daily briefing: Furore over ‘oldest pyramid’ claim
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03767-z

A paper claiming that a structure in Indonesia is the oldest pyramid in the world has raised the eyebrows of archaeologists. Plus, some anglerfish species live life upside down and babies start learning language in the womb.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Furore over ‘oldest pyramid’ claim
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: This sparrow massively expands part of its brain in preparation for mating
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03746-4

The trick baffles researchers — but they are getting closer to understanding how the songbird does it.
item.dc:title: This sparrow massively expands part of its brain in preparation for mating
item.dc:creator: Anil Oza

item.title: A 27,000-year-old pyramid? Controversy hits an extraordinary archaeological claim
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 28 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03546-w

The massive buried structures at Gunung Padang in Indonesia would be far older than Egypt’s great pyramids — if they’re even human constructions at all.
item.dc:title: A 27,000-year-old pyramid? Controversy hits an extraordinary archaeological claim
item.dc:creator: Dyani Lewis

item.title: Publisher Correction: Dopaminergic systems create reward seeking despite adverse consequences
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06876-x

Publisher Correction: Dopaminergic systems create reward seeking despite adverse consequences
item.dc:title: Publisher Correction: Dopaminergic systems create reward seeking despite adverse consequences
item.dc:creator: Kristijan D. Jovanoski

Sai Parepalli
Paola Cognigni
Nils Otto
Johannes Felsenberg

item.title: Deep, deep down: a day in the life of a subterranean biologist
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03723-x

Špela Borko tells how cave-diving enhanced her appreciation of the myriad life forms that teem in underground lakes.
item.dc:title: Deep, deep down: a day in the life of a subterranean biologist
item.dc:creator: Stav Dimitropoulos

item.title: California wildlife pays the cost of megafires
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03701-3

Increasingly intense wildfires in the United States could have profound impacts on natural habitats — potentially leaving hundreds of animal species struggling to recover.
item.dc:title: California wildlife pays the cost of megafires
item.dc:creator: Holly Smith

item.title: What’s behind China’s mysterious wave of childhood pneumonia?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03732-w

Scientists expected a surge in respiratory disease, but what is happening in China is unusual.
item.dc:title: What’s behind China’s mysterious wave of childhood pneumonia?
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: Daily briefing: What’s causing a pneumonia surge in China
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03761-5

A spike in respiratory illnesses in children is the result of common winter infections — not a novel pathogen. Plus, how to stop waves in their tracks and why we might embrace the feeling of uncertainty.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: What’s causing a pneumonia surge in China
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Chemistry is inaccessible: how to reduce barriers for disabled scientists
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03634-x

From classrooms to laboratories and conferences, working in chemistry presents huge challenges to disabled, chronically ill and neurodivergent people. Some simple fixes can help to shift the dial.
item.dc:title: Chemistry is inaccessible: how to reduce barriers for disabled scientists
item.dc:creator: Blaine G. Fiss
Laena D’Alton
Naumih M. Noah

item.title: Putting low-cost diagnostics to the test
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03576-4

The COVID-19 pandemic brought home the value of cheap, ‘good enough’ methods of detecting disease. Extending that approach to other illnesses could improve health care in low- and middle-income countries.
item.dc:title: Putting low-cost diagnostics to the test
item.dc:creator: Michael Eisenstein

item.title: AI under the microscope: the algorithms powering the search for cells
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03722-y

Deep learning is driving the rapid evolution of algorithms that can automatically find and trace cells in a wide range of microscopy experiments.
item.dc:title: AI under the microscope: the algorithms powering the search for cells
item.dc:creator: Michael Eisenstein

item.title: 15 years after a giant leap for cancer genomics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03626-x

In 2008, the first comprehensive sequence of a cancer genome was reported, ushering in a new era of molecular diagnostic, prognostic and therapeutic advances informed by an essential framework to understand cancer’s complexities.
item.dc:title: 15 years after a giant leap for cancer genomics
item.dc:creator: Sheng F. Cai
Ross L. Levine

item.title: Audio long read: Apple revival — how science is bringing historic varieties back to life
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03640-z

Genomic studies of heirloom apples could help safeguard the future of the fruit.
item.dc:title: Audio long read: Apple revival — how science is bringing historic varieties back to life
item.dc:creator: Christopher Kemp
Benjamin Thompson

item.title: ‘Early dark energy’ fails to solve mystery of cosmic expansion
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03559-5

The extra ingredient would explain why the Universe is expanding so fast now — but conflicts with data from ancient quasars.
item.dc:title: ‘Early dark energy’ fails to solve mystery of cosmic expansion

item.title: Daily briefing: What we can learn from disasters that were averted
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03737-5

Tornadoes, earthquakes and wildfires don’t have to lead to death and destruction. Plus, the most powerful cosmic ray since the Oh-My-God particle and a ‘treasure trove’ of new CRISPR systems holds promise for genome editing.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: What we can learn from disasters that were averted
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: Anthropocene briefing: What it will take to stay below 1.5 °C
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03744-6

Can the world get back on track with efforts to stay under 1.5 ℃ of warming? Plus: The US is set to announce its strategy for international partnerships to commercialize nuclear-fusion power.
item.dc:title: Anthropocene briefing: What it will take to stay below 1.5 °C
item.dc:creator: Jesse Chase-Lubitz

item.title: How ChatGPT and sounds from space brought a ‘luminous jelly’ to life
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03392-w

Engineer-turned-artist Diana Scarborough and inorganic chemist Anna Melekhova describe how their art–science collaboration gave voice and form to a new material.
item.dc:title: How ChatGPT and sounds from space brought a ‘luminous jelly’ to life
item.dc:creator: Julie Gould
